trans-unit.source: Monitor and manage Azure Data Factory pipelines
trans-unit.target: Monitor and manage Azure Data Factory pipelines

trans-unit.source: Learn how to use Azure Management Portal and Azure PowerShell to monitor and manage Azure data factories and pipelines you have created.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to use Azure Management Portal and Azure PowerShell to monitor and manage Azure data factories and pipelines you have created.

trans-unit.source: Monitor and manage Azure Data Factory pipelines
trans-unit.target: Monitor and manage Azure Data Factory pipelines

trans-unit.source: The Data Factory service provides reliable and complete view of your storage, processing, and data movement services.
trans-unit.target: The Data Factory service provides reliable and complete view of your storage, processing, and data movement services.

trans-unit.source: It helps you quickly assess end-to-end data pipeline health, pinpoint issues, and take corrective action if needed.
trans-unit.target: It helps you quickly assess end-to-end data pipeline health, pinpoint issues, and take corrective action if needed.

trans-unit.source: You can also visually track data lineage and the relationships between your data across any of your sources, and see a full historical accounting of job execution, system health, and dependencies from a single monitoring dashboard.
trans-unit.target: You can also visually track data lineage and the relationships between your data across any of your sources, and see a full historical accounting of job execution, system health, and dependencies from a single monitoring dashboard.

trans-unit.source: This article describes how to monitor, manage and debug your pipelines.
trans-unit.target: This article describes how to monitor, manage and debug your pipelines.

trans-unit.source: It also provides information on how to create alerts and get notified on failures.
trans-unit.target: It also provides information on how to create alerts and get notified on failures.

trans-unit.source: Understand pipelines and activity states
trans-unit.target: Understand pipelines and activity states

trans-unit.source: Using the Azure Preview Portal, you can view your data factory as a diagram, view activities in a pipeline, view input and output datasets, and more.
trans-unit.target: Using the Azure Preview Portal, you can view your data factory as a diagram, view activities in a pipeline, view input and output datasets, and more.

trans-unit.source: This section also provides how a slice transitions from one state to another state.
trans-unit.target: This section also provides how a slice transitions from one state to another state.

trans-unit.source: Navigate to your data factory
trans-unit.target: Navigate to your data factory

trans-unit.source: Sign-in to the [Azure Preview Portal](http://portal.azure.com).
trans-unit.target: Sign-in to the [Azure Preview Portal](http://portal.azure.com).

trans-unit.source: Click **Browse All** and select **Data Factories**.
trans-unit.target: Click **Browse All** and select **Data Factories**.

trans-unit.source: Browse All -> Data factories
trans-unit.target: Browse All -> Data factories

trans-unit.source: You should see all the data factories in the **Data factories** blade.
trans-unit.target: You should see all the data factories in the **Data factories** blade.

trans-unit.source: In the Data factories blade, select the data factory you are interested in and you should see the home page (**Data factory** blade) for the data factory.
trans-unit.target: In the Data factories blade, select the data factory you are interested in and you should see the home page (**Data factory** blade) for the data factory.

trans-unit.source: Data factory blade
trans-unit.target: Data factory blade

trans-unit.source: Diagram view of your data factory
trans-unit.target: Diagram view of your data factory

trans-unit.source: The Diagram View of a data factory provides a single pane of glass to monitor and manage the data factory and its assets.
trans-unit.target: The Diagram View of a data factory provides a single pane of glass to monitor and manage the data factory and its assets.

trans-unit.source: Click **Diagram** on the data factory home page above to see the diagram view of your data factory.
trans-unit.target: Click **Diagram** on the data factory home page above to see the diagram view of your data factory.

trans-unit.source: Diagram view
trans-unit.target: Diagram view

trans-unit.source: You can zoom in, zoom out, zoom to fit, zoom to 100%, lock the layout of the diagram, automaticaly position pipelines and tables, and show lineage (show upstream and downstream items of selected items).
trans-unit.target: You can zoom in, zoom out, zoom to fit, zoom to 100%, lock the layout of the diagram, automaticaly position pipelines and tables, and show lineage (show upstream and downstream items of selected items).

trans-unit.source: Activities inside a pipeline
trans-unit.target: Activities inside a pipeline

trans-unit.source: Right-click on the pipeline and click **Open pipeline** to see all activities in the pipeline along with input and output datasets for the activities.
trans-unit.target: Right-click on the pipeline and click **Open pipeline** to see all activities in the pipeline along with input and output datasets for the activities.

trans-unit.source: This is useful when your pipeline comprises of more than 1 Activity and you want to understand the operational lineage of a single pipeline.
trans-unit.target: This is useful when your pipeline comprises of more than 1 Activity and you want to understand the operational lineage of a single pipeline.

trans-unit.source: Open pipeline menu
trans-unit.target: Open pipeline menu

trans-unit.source: In the following example, you see two activities in the pipeline with their inputs and outputs.
trans-unit.target: In the following example, you see two activities in the pipeline with their inputs and outputs.

trans-unit.source: The activity titled **JoinData** of type HDInsight Hive Activity and **EgressDataAzure** of type Copy Activity are in this sample pipeline.
trans-unit.target: The activity titled **JoinData** of type HDInsight Hive Activity and **EgressDataAzure** of type Copy Activity are in this sample pipeline.

trans-unit.source: Activities inside a pipeline
trans-unit.target: Activities inside a pipeline

trans-unit.source: You can navigate back to Data Factory home page by clicking Data factory link in the breadcrumb in the top-left corner.
trans-unit.target: You can navigate back to Data Factory home page by clicking Data factory link in the breadcrumb in the top-left corner.

trans-unit.source: Navigate back to data factory
trans-unit.target: Navigate back to data factory

trans-unit.source: View state of each activity inside a pipeline
trans-unit.target: View state of each activity inside a pipeline

trans-unit.source: You can view the current state of an activity by viewing the status of any of the datasets produced by the activity.
trans-unit.target: You can view the current state of an activity by viewing the status of any of the datasets produced by the activity.

trans-unit.source: For example: in the following example, the **BlobPartitionHiveActivity** ran successfully and produced a dataset named **PartitionedProductsUsageTable** which is in **Ready** state.
trans-unit.target: For example: in the following example, the **BlobPartitionHiveActivity** ran successfully and produced a dataset named **PartitionedProductsUsageTable** which is in **Ready** state.

trans-unit.source: State of pipeline
trans-unit.target: State of pipeline

trans-unit.source: Double clicking the **PartitionedProductsUsageTable** in the diagram view will showcase all the slices produced by different activity runs inside a pipeline.
trans-unit.target: Double clicking the **PartitionedProductsUsageTable** in the diagram view will showcase all the slices produced by different activity runs inside a pipeline.

trans-unit.source: You can see that the **BlobPartitionHiveActivity** ran successfully every month for last 8 months and produced the slices in **Ready** state.
trans-unit.target: You can see that the **BlobPartitionHiveActivity** ran successfully every month for last 8 months and produced the slices in **Ready** state.

trans-unit.source: The dataset slices in data factory can have one of the following status:
trans-unit.target: The dataset slices in data factory can have one of the following status:

trans-unit.source: Status
trans-unit.target: Status

trans-unit.source: Sub status
trans-unit.target: Sub status

trans-unit.source: Description
trans-unit.target: Description

trans-unit.source: Waiting
trans-unit.target: Waiting

trans-unit.source: ScheduledTime
trans-unit.target: ScheduledTime

trans-unit.source: DatasetDependencies
trans-unit.target: DatasetDependencies

trans-unit.source: ComputeResources
trans-unit.target: ComputeResources

trans-unit.source: ConcurrencyLimit
trans-unit.target: ConcurrencyLimit

trans-unit.source: ActivityResume
trans-unit.target: ActivityResume

trans-unit.source: Retry
trans-unit.target: Retry

trans-unit.target: Validation

trans-unit.source: ValidationRetry
trans-unit.target: ValidationRetry

trans-unit.source: Waiting for pre-conditions to be met before executing.
trans-unit.target: Waiting for pre-conditions to be met before executing.

trans-unit.source: Refer to the sub status to figure out what the slice is waiting for.
trans-unit.target: Refer to the sub status to figure out what the slice is waiting for.

trans-unit.target: In-Progress

trans-unit.source: Starting
trans-unit.target: Starting

trans-unit.source: Configuring
trans-unit.target: Configuring

trans-unit.source: Allocating Resources
trans-unit.target: Allocating Resources

trans-unit.target: Running

trans-unit.source: Validating
trans-unit.target: Validating

trans-unit.source: Currently, the activity is executing and producing/validating the data for a specific slice.
trans-unit.target: Currently, the activity is executing and producing/validating the data for a specific slice.

trans-unit.source: Failed
trans-unit.target: Failed

trans-unit.source: Slice processing failed.
trans-unit.target: Slice processing failed.

trans-unit.source: Refer to error logs to figure out what caused the failure
trans-unit.target: Refer to error logs to figure out what caused the failure

trans-unit.source: Ready
trans-unit.target: Ready

trans-unit.source: Slice processing succeeded.
trans-unit.target: Slice processing succeeded.

trans-unit.source: Slice is ready for consumption.
trans-unit.target: Slice is ready for consumption.

trans-unit.source: Skip
trans-unit.target: Skip

trans-unit.source: Do not process this slice
trans-unit.target: Do not process this slice

trans-unit.source: You can view the details about a slice by clicking a slice entry in the **Recently Updated Slices** blade.
trans-unit.target: You can view the details about a slice by clicking a slice entry in the **Recently Updated Slices** blade.

trans-unit.source: Slice details
trans-unit.target: Slice details

trans-unit.source: If the slice has been executed multiple times, you will see multiple rows in the **Activity runs** list.
trans-unit.target: If the slice has been executed multiple times, you will see multiple rows in the **Activity runs** list.

trans-unit.source: Activity runs for a slice
trans-unit.target: Activity runs for a slice

trans-unit.source: You can view details about an activity run by clicking the run entry in the **Activity runs** list.
trans-unit.target: You can view details about an activity run by clicking the run entry in the **Activity runs** list.

trans-unit.source: This will showcase all the log files along with an error message if any.
trans-unit.target: This will showcase all the log files along with an error message if any.

trans-unit.source: This is very useful to view and debug logs without having to leave your data factory.
trans-unit.target: This is very useful to view and debug logs without having to leave your data factory.

trans-unit.source: Activity run details
trans-unit.target: Activity run details

trans-unit.source: If the slice is not in the **Ready** state, you can see the upstream slices that are not ready and are blocking the current slice from executing in the **Upstream slices that are not ready** list.
trans-unit.target: If the slice is not in the **Ready** state, you can see the upstream slices that are not ready and are blocking the current slice from executing in the **Upstream slices that are not ready** list.

trans-unit.source: This is very useful when your slice is in **Waiting** state and you want to understand the upstream dependencies on which the slice is waiting.
trans-unit.target: This is very useful when your slice is in **Waiting** state and you want to understand the upstream dependencies on which the slice is waiting.

trans-unit.source: Upstream slices not ready
trans-unit.target: Upstream slices not ready

trans-unit.source: Dataset State Diagram
trans-unit.target: Dataset State Diagram

trans-unit.source: Once you deploy a data factory and the pipelines have a valid active period, the dataset slices transition from one state to another.
trans-unit.target: Once you deploy a data factory and the pipelines have a valid active period, the dataset slices transition from one state to another.

trans-unit.source: Currently the slice status follows the following state diagram:
trans-unit.target: Currently the slice status follows the following state diagram:

trans-unit.source: State diagram
trans-unit.target: State diagram

trans-unit.source: The dataset state transition flow in data factory involves the following:
trans-unit.target: The dataset state transition flow in data factory involves the following:

trans-unit.source: Waiting-> In-Progress/In-Progress (Validating) -> Ready/Failed
trans-unit.target: Waiting-> In-Progress/In-Progress (Validating) -> Ready/Failed

trans-unit.source: The slices start in a **Waiting** state for pre-conditions to be met before executing.
trans-unit.target: The slices start in a **Waiting** state for pre-conditions to be met before executing.

trans-unit.source: Followed by this, the activity starts executing and the slice goes in **In-Progress** state.
trans-unit.target: Followed by this, the activity starts executing and the slice goes in **In-Progress** state.

trans-unit.source: The activity execution could be successful or fail and based on that the slice will go either in **Ready**’ or **Failed** state.
trans-unit.target: The activity execution could be successful or fail and based on that the slice will go either in **Ready**’ or **Failed** state.

trans-unit.source: The user can reset the slice to go back from **Ready** or **Failed** state to **Waiting** state.
trans-unit.target: The user can reset the slice to go back from **Ready** or **Failed** state to **Waiting** state.

trans-unit.source: The user can also mark the slice state to **Skip** which will prevent the activity from executing and not process the slice.
trans-unit.target: The user can also mark the slice state to **Skip** which will prevent the activity from executing and not process the slice.

trans-unit.source: Manage pipelines
trans-unit.target: Manage pipelines

trans-unit.source: You can manage your pipelines using Azure PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: You can manage your pipelines using Azure PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: For example, you can pause and resume pipelines by running Azure PowerShell cmdlets.
trans-unit.target: For example, you can pause and resume pipelines by running Azure PowerShell cmdlets.

trans-unit.source: Pause and resume pipelines
trans-unit.target: Pause and resume pipelines

trans-unit.source: You can pause/suspend pipelines using the **Suspend-AzureDataFactoryPipeline** Powershell cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: You can pause/suspend pipelines using the **Suspend-AzureDataFactoryPipeline** Powershell cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: This is useful when you have figured out an issue with your data and don’t want to run your pipelines to process data any further until the issue is fixed.
trans-unit.target: This is useful when you have figured out an issue with your data and don’t want to run your pipelines to process data any further until the issue is fixed.

trans-unit.source: For example: in the below screen shot, an issue has been identified with the **PartitionProductsUsagePipeline** in **productrecgamalbox1dev** data factory and we want to suspend the pipeline.
trans-unit.target: For example: in the below screen shot, an issue has been identified with the **PartitionProductsUsagePipeline** in **productrecgamalbox1dev** data factory and we want to suspend the pipeline.

trans-unit.source: Pipeline to be suspended
trans-unit.target: Pipeline to be suspended

trans-unit.source: Run the following PowerShell command to suspend the **PartitionProductsUsagePipeline**.
trans-unit.target: Run the following PowerShell command to suspend the **PartitionProductsUsagePipeline**.

trans-unit.source: For example:
trans-unit.target: For example:

trans-unit.source: Once the issue has been fixed with the **PartitionProductsUsagePipeline**, the suspended pipeline can be resumed by running the following PowerShell command.
trans-unit.target: Once the issue has been fixed with the **PartitionProductsUsagePipeline**, the suspended pipeline can be resumed by running the following PowerShell command.

trans-unit.source: For example:
trans-unit.target: For example:

trans-unit.source: Debug pipelines
trans-unit.target: Debug pipelines

trans-unit.source: Azure Data Factory provides rich capabilities via Azure portal and Azure PowerShell to debug and troubleshoot pipelines.
trans-unit.target: Azure Data Factory provides rich capabilities via Azure portal and Azure PowerShell to debug and troubleshoot pipelines.

trans-unit.source: Find errors in a pipeline
trans-unit.target: Find errors in a pipeline

trans-unit.source: If the activity run fails in a pipeline, the dataset produced by the pipeline is in an error state due to the failure.
trans-unit.target: If the activity run fails in a pipeline, the dataset produced by the pipeline is in an error state due to the failure.

trans-unit.source: You can debug and troubleshoot errors in Azure Data Factory using the following mechanisms.
trans-unit.target: You can debug and troubleshoot errors in Azure Data Factory using the following mechanisms.

trans-unit.source: Use Azure Portal to debug an error:
trans-unit.target: Use Azure Portal to debug an error:

trans-unit.source: Click **With errors** on **Datasets** tile on the data factory home page.
trans-unit.target: Click **With errors** on **Datasets** tile on the data factory home page.

trans-unit.source: Datasets tile with error
trans-unit.target: Datasets tile with error

trans-unit.source: In the **Datasets with errors** blade, click the table that you are interested in.
trans-unit.target: In the **Datasets with errors** blade, click the table that you are interested in.

trans-unit.source: Datasets with errors blade
trans-unit.target: Datasets with errors blade

trans-unit.source: In the **TABLE** blade, click on the problem slice with **STATUS** set to **Failed**.
trans-unit.target: In the **TABLE** blade, click on the problem slice with **STATUS** set to **Failed**.

trans-unit.source: Table blade with problem slice
trans-unit.target: Table blade with problem slice

trans-unit.source: In the **DATA SLICE** blade, click the activity run that failed.
trans-unit.target: In the **DATA SLICE** blade, click the activity run that failed.

trans-unit.source: Dataslice with an error
trans-unit.target: Dataslice with an error

trans-unit.source: In the **ACTIVITY RUN DETAILS** blade, you can download the files associated with the HDInsight processing.
trans-unit.target: In the **ACTIVITY RUN DETAILS** blade, you can download the files associated with the HDInsight processing.

trans-unit.source: Click Download for Status/stderr to download the error log file that contains details about the error.
trans-unit.target: Click Download for Status/stderr to download the error log file that contains details about the error.

trans-unit.source: Activity run details blade with error
trans-unit.target: Activity run details blade with error

trans-unit.source: Use the PowerShell to debug an error
trans-unit.target: Use the PowerShell to debug an error

trans-unit.source: Launch **Azure PowerShell**.
trans-unit.target: Launch **Azure PowerShell**.

trans-unit.source: Switch to **AzureResourceManager** mode as the Data Factory cmdlets are available only in this mode.
trans-unit.target: Switch to **AzureResourceManager** mode as the Data Factory cmdlets are available only in this mode.

trans-unit.source: Run **Get-AzureDataFactorySlice** command to see the slices and their statuses.
trans-unit.target: Run **Get-AzureDataFactorySlice** command to see the slices and their statuses.

trans-unit.source: You should see a slice with the status: **Failed**.
trans-unit.target: You should see a slice with the status: **Failed**.

trans-unit.source: For example:
trans-unit.target: For example:

trans-unit.source: Now, run the **Get-AzureDataFactoryRun** cmdlet to get details about activity run for the slice.
trans-unit.target: Now, run the **Get-AzureDataFactoryRun** cmdlet to get details about activity run for the slice.

trans-unit.source: For example:
trans-unit.target: For example:

trans-unit.source: You should see the output with details about the error (similar to the following):
trans-unit.target: You should see the output with details about the error (similar to the following):

trans-unit.source: You can run **Save-AzureDataFactoryLog** cmdlet with Id value you see from the above output and download the log files using the **-DownloadLogsoption** for the cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: You can run **Save-AzureDataFactoryLog** cmdlet with Id value you see from the above output and download the log files using the **-DownloadLogsoption** for the cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: Save-AzureDataFactoryLog -ResourceGroupName "ADF" -DataFactoryName "LogProcessingFactory" -Id "841b77c9-d56c-48d1-99a3-8c16c3e77d39" -DownloadLogs -Output "C:\Test"
trans-unit.target: Save-AzureDataFactoryLog -ResourceGroupName "ADF" -DataFactoryName "LogProcessingFactory" -Id "841b77c9-d56c-48d1-99a3-8c16c3e77d39" -DownloadLogs -Output "C:\Test"

trans-unit.source: Re-run failures in a pipeline
trans-unit.target: Re-run failures in a pipeline

trans-unit.source: Using Azure Portal
trans-unit.target: Using Azure Portal

trans-unit.source: Once you troubleshoot and debug failures in a pipeline, you can re-run failures by navigating to the error slice and clicking the **Run** button on the command bar.
trans-unit.target: Once you troubleshoot and debug failures in a pipeline, you can re-run failures by navigating to the error slice and clicking the **Run** button on the command bar.

trans-unit.source: Rerun a failed slice
trans-unit.target: Rerun a failed slice

trans-unit.source: In case the slice has failed validation due to a policy failure (for ex: data not available), you can fix the failure and validate again by clicking the **Validate** button on the command bar.
trans-unit.target: In case the slice has failed validation due to a policy failure (for ex: data not available), you can fix the failure and validate again by clicking the **Validate** button on the command bar.

trans-unit.source: ![Fix errors and validate](./media/data-factory-monitor-manage-pipelines/fix-error-and-validate.png)
trans-unit.target: ![Fix errors and validate](./media/data-factory-monitor-manage-pipelines/fix-error-and-validate.png)

trans-unit.source: Using Azure PowerShell
trans-unit.target: Using Azure PowerShell

trans-unit.source: You can re-run failures by using the ‘Set-AzureDataFactorySliceStatus’ cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: You can re-run failures by using the ‘Set-AzureDataFactorySliceStatus’ cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: **Example:**
trans-unit.target: **Example:**

trans-unit.source: The following example sets the status of all slices for the table 'DAWikiAggregatedData' to 'PendingExecution' in the Azure data factory 'WikiADF'.
trans-unit.target: The following example sets the status of all slices for the table 'DAWikiAggregatedData' to 'PendingExecution' in the Azure data factory 'WikiADF'.

trans-unit.source: **Note:** The UpdateType is set to UpstreamInPipeline, which means that status of each slice for the table and all the dependent (upstream) tables which are used as input tables for activities in the pipeline is set to "PendingExecution".
trans-unit.target: **Note:** The UpdateType is set to UpstreamInPipeline, which means that status of each slice for the table and all the dependent (upstream) tables which are used as input tables for activities in the pipeline is set to "PendingExecution".

trans-unit.source: Other possible value for this parameter is "Individual".
trans-unit.target: Other possible value for this parameter is "Individual".

trans-unit.source: Create alerts
trans-unit.target: Create alerts

trans-unit.source: Azure logs user events when an Azure resource (e.g. data factory) is created, updated or deleted.
trans-unit.target: Azure logs user events when an Azure resource (e.g. data factory) is created, updated or deleted.

trans-unit.source: You can create alerts on these events.
trans-unit.target: You can create alerts on these events.

trans-unit.source: Data Factory allows you to capture various metrics and create alerts on metrics.
trans-unit.target: Data Factory allows you to capture various metrics and create alerts on metrics.

trans-unit.source: We recommend that you use events for real time monitoring and metrics for historical purposes.
trans-unit.target: We recommend that you use events for real time monitoring and metrics for historical purposes.

trans-unit.source: Alerts on events
trans-unit.target: Alerts on events

trans-unit.source: Azure events provide useful insights into what is happening in your Azure resources.
trans-unit.target: Azure events provide useful insights into what is happening in your Azure resources.

trans-unit.source: Azure logs user events when an Azure resource (e.g. data factory) is created, updated or deleted.
trans-unit.target: Azure logs user events when an Azure resource (e.g. data factory) is created, updated or deleted.

trans-unit.source: When using the Azure Data Factory, events are generated when:
trans-unit.target: When using the Azure Data Factory, events are generated when:

trans-unit.source: Azure Data Factory is created/updated/deleted.
trans-unit.target: Azure Data Factory is created/updated/deleted.

trans-unit.source: Data processing (called as Runs) has started/completed.
trans-unit.target: Data processing (called as Runs) has started/completed.

trans-unit.source: When an on-demand HDInsight cluster is created and removed.
trans-unit.target: When an on-demand HDInsight cluster is created and removed.

trans-unit.source: You can create alerts on these user events and configure them to send email notifications to the administrator and co-administrators of the subscription.
trans-unit.target: You can create alerts on these user events and configure them to send email notifications to the administrator and co-administrators of the subscription.

trans-unit.source: In addition, you can specify additional email addresses of users who need to receive email notifications when the conditions are met.
trans-unit.target: In addition, you can specify additional email addresses of users who need to receive email notifications when the conditions are met.

trans-unit.source: This is very useful when you want to get notified on failures and don’t want to continuously monitor your data factory.
trans-unit.target: This is very useful when you want to get notified on failures and don’t want to continuously monitor your data factory.

trans-unit.source: Specifying an alert definition:
trans-unit.target: Specifying an alert definition:

trans-unit.source: To specify an alert definition, you create a JSON file describing the operations that you want to be alerted on.
trans-unit.target: To specify an alert definition, you create a JSON file describing the operations that you want to be alerted on.

trans-unit.source: In the example below, the alert will send an email notification for the RunFinished operation.
trans-unit.target: In the example below, the alert will send an email notification for the RunFinished operation.

trans-unit.source: To be specific, an email notification is sent when a run in the data factory has completed and the run has failed (Status = FailedExecution).
trans-unit.target: To be specific, an email notification is sent when a run in the data factory has completed and the run has failed (Status = FailedExecution).

trans-unit.source: From the above JSON definition, **subStatus** can be removed if you don’t want to be alerted on a specific failure.
trans-unit.target: From the above JSON definition, **subStatus** can be removed if you don’t want to be alerted on a specific failure.

trans-unit.source: The following table provides the list of available operations and statuses (and sub-statuses).
trans-unit.target: The following table provides the list of available operations and statuses (and sub-statuses).

trans-unit.source: Operation name
trans-unit.target: Operation name

trans-unit.source: Status
trans-unit.target: Status

trans-unit.source: Sub status
trans-unit.target: Sub status

trans-unit.source: RunStarted
trans-unit.target: RunStarted

trans-unit.source: Started
trans-unit.target: Started

trans-unit.source: Starting
trans-unit.target: Starting

trans-unit.source: RunFinished
trans-unit.target: RunFinished

trans-unit.source: Failed / Succeeded
trans-unit.target: Failed / Succeeded

trans-unit.source: FailedResourceAllocation
trans-unit.target: FailedResourceAllocation

trans-unit.source: Succeeded
trans-unit.target: Succeeded

trans-unit.source: FailedExecution
trans-unit.target: FailedExecution

trans-unit.source: TimedOut
trans-unit.target: TimedOut

trans-unit.source: <Canceled/p>
trans-unit.target: <Canceled/p>

trans-unit.source: FailedValidation
trans-unit.target: FailedValidation

trans-unit.source: Abandoned
trans-unit.target: Abandoned

trans-unit.source: SliceOnTime
trans-unit.target: SliceOnTime

trans-unit.source: In Progress
trans-unit.target: In Progress

trans-unit.source: Ontime
trans-unit.target: Ontime

trans-unit.source: SliceDelayed
trans-unit.target: SliceDelayed

trans-unit.source: In Progress
trans-unit.target: In Progress

trans-unit.source: Late
trans-unit.target: Late

trans-unit.source: OnDemandClusterCreateStarted
trans-unit.target: OnDemandClusterCreateStarted

trans-unit.source: Started
trans-unit.target: Started

trans-unit.source: OnDemandClusterCreateSuccessful
trans-unit.target: OnDemandClusterCreateSuccessful

trans-unit.source: Succeeded
trans-unit.target: Succeeded

trans-unit.source: OnDemandClusterDeleted
trans-unit.target: OnDemandClusterDeleted

trans-unit.source: Succeeded
trans-unit.target: Succeeded

trans-unit.source: Deploying the Alert
trans-unit.target: Deploying the Alert

trans-unit.source: To deploy the alert, use the Azure PowerShell cmdlet: **New-AzureResourceGroupDeployment**, as shown in the following example:
trans-unit.target: To deploy the alert, use the Azure PowerShell cmdlet: **New-AzureResourceGroupDeployment**, as shown in the following example:

trans-unit.source: Once the resource group deployment has completed successfully, you will see the following messages:
trans-unit.target: Once the resource group deployment has completed successfully, you will see the following messages:

trans-unit.source: Retrieving the list of Azure Resource Group Deployments
trans-unit.target: Retrieving the list of Azure Resource Group Deployments

trans-unit.source: To retrieve the list of deployed Azure Resource Group deployments, use the cmdlet: **Get-AzureResourceGroupDeployment**, as shown in the following example:
trans-unit.target: To retrieve the list of deployed Azure Resource Group deployments, use the cmdlet: **Get-AzureResourceGroupDeployment**, as shown in the following example:

trans-unit.source: Troubleshooting User Events
trans-unit.target: Troubleshooting User Events

trans-unit.source: You can see all the events generated after clicking on the **Operations** tile, and alerts can be setup on any of these operations visible on the **Events** blade:
trans-unit.target: You can see all the events generated after clicking on the **Operations** tile, and alerts can be setup on any of these operations visible on the **Events** blade:

trans-unit.source: Operations
trans-unit.target: Operations

trans-unit.source: To see the alerts setup using Power shell, you can run the following command, and see all the alerts created.
trans-unit.target: To see the alerts setup using Power shell, you can run the following command, and see all the alerts created.

trans-unit.source: This will show the alerts set up for both metrics and events with resource type as **microsoft.insights/alertrules**.
trans-unit.target: This will show the alerts set up for both metrics and events with resource type as **microsoft.insights/alertrules**.

trans-unit.source: If you see the alert generation events on the portal blade but you don't receive email notifications, check whether e-mail address specified is set to receive emails from external senders.
trans-unit.target: If you see the alert generation events on the portal blade but you don't receive email notifications, check whether e-mail address specified is set to receive emails from external senders.

trans-unit.source: The alert e-mails may have been blocked by your e-mail settings.
trans-unit.target: The alert e-mails may have been blocked by your e-mail settings.

trans-unit.source: Alerts on Metrics
trans-unit.target: Alerts on Metrics

trans-unit.source: Data Factory allows you to capture various metrics and create alerts on metrics.
trans-unit.target: Data Factory allows you to capture various metrics and create alerts on metrics.

trans-unit.source: You can monitor and create alerts on the following metrics for the slices in your data factory.
trans-unit.target: You can monitor and create alerts on the following metrics for the slices in your data factory.

trans-unit.source: Failed Runs
trans-unit.target: Failed Runs

trans-unit.source: Successful Runs
trans-unit.target: Successful Runs

trans-unit.source: These metrics are very useful and allow users to get an overview of overall failed and successful runs in their data factory.
trans-unit.target: These metrics are very useful and allow users to get an overview of overall failed and successful runs in their data factory.

trans-unit.source: Metrics are emitted every time there is a slice run.
trans-unit.target: Metrics are emitted every time there is a slice run.

trans-unit.source: On top of the hour, these metrics are aggregated and pushed to your storage account.
trans-unit.target: On top of the hour, these metrics are aggregated and pushed to your storage account.

trans-unit.source: Therefore, to enable metrics, you will need to setup a storage account.
trans-unit.target: Therefore, to enable metrics, you will need to setup a storage account.

trans-unit.source: Enabling Metrics:
trans-unit.target: Enabling Metrics:

trans-unit.source: To enable metrics, please click on the following from Data Factory blade:
trans-unit.target: To enable metrics, please click on the following from Data Factory blade:

trans-unit.source: **Monitoring** -> **Metric** -> **Diagnostic settings** -> **Diagnostic**
trans-unit.target: **Monitoring** -> **Metric** -> **Diagnostic settings** -> **Diagnostic**

trans-unit.source: On the **Diagnostic** blade, click **On** and select the storage account and save.
trans-unit.target: On the **Diagnostic** blade, click **On** and select the storage account and save.

trans-unit.source: Enable metrics
trans-unit.target: Enable metrics

trans-unit.source: Once saved, it may to take up to one hour for the metrics to be visible on the monitoring blade, because metrics aggregation happens hourly.
trans-unit.target: Once saved, it may to take up to one hour for the metrics to be visible on the monitoring blade, because metrics aggregation happens hourly.

trans-unit.source: Setting up alert on Metrics:
trans-unit.target: Setting up alert on Metrics:

trans-unit.source: To set up alerting on Metrics, click on the following from Data factory blade:
trans-unit.target: To set up alerting on Metrics, click on the following from Data factory blade:

trans-unit.source: **Monitoring** -> **Metric** -> **Add alert** -> **Add an alert rule**.
trans-unit.target: **Monitoring** -> **Metric** -> **Add alert** -> **Add an alert rule**.

trans-unit.source: Fill in the details for alert rule, specify emails and click **OK**.
trans-unit.target: Fill in the details for alert rule, specify emails and click **OK**.

trans-unit.source: Setting up alerts on metrics
trans-unit.target: Setting up alerts on metrics

trans-unit.source: Once done, you should see a new alert rule enabled on Alert rules tile as following:
trans-unit.target: Once done, you should see a new alert rule enabled on Alert rules tile as following:

trans-unit.source: Alert rules enabled
trans-unit.target: Alert rules enabled

trans-unit.source: Congratulations!
trans-unit.target: Congratulations!

trans-unit.source: You have set up your first alert on Metrics.
trans-unit.target: You have set up your first alert on Metrics.

trans-unit.source: Now you should get notifications every time alert rule matches in the given time window.
trans-unit.target: Now you should get notifications every time alert rule matches in the given time window.

trans-unit.source: Alert notifications:
trans-unit.target: Alert notifications:

trans-unit.source: Once the setup rule matches the condition, you should get an alert activated email.
trans-unit.target: Once the setup rule matches the condition, you should get an alert activated email.

trans-unit.source: Once the issue is resolved and the alert condition doesn’t match any more, you will get alert resolved email.
trans-unit.target: Once the issue is resolved and the alert condition doesn’t match any more, you will get alert resolved email.

trans-unit.source: This behavior is different than events where a notification will be sent on each and every failure for which alert rule qualify.
trans-unit.target: This behavior is different than events where a notification will be sent on each and every failure for which alert rule qualify.

trans-unit.source: Deploying alerts using PowerShell
trans-unit.target: Deploying alerts using PowerShell

trans-unit.source: You can deploy alerts for metrics in the same way as you do for events.
trans-unit.target: You can deploy alerts for metrics in the same way as you do for events.

trans-unit.source: Alert definition:
trans-unit.target: Alert definition:

trans-unit.target: Replace subscriptionId, resourceGroupName, and dataFactoryName in the above sample with appropriate values.

trans-unit.source: *metricName* as of now supports 2 values:
trans-unit.target: *metricName* as of now supports 2 values:

trans-unit.target: FailedRuns

trans-unit.source: SuccessfulRuns
trans-unit.target: SuccessfulRuns

trans-unit.target: Deploying the alert:

trans-unit.target: To deploy the alert, use the Azure PowerShell cmdlet: **New-AzureResourceGroupDeployment**, as shown in the following example:
